fields.physical_description: Feathered fan (yellow and brown feathers) with carved hardstone or glass handle, mounted with 2 small red stone on either side of the handle. Carvings on handle made in style of geometric incisions on ancient bronzes.
fields.materials_techniques: Feathers with carved hardstone or glass
fields.public_access_description:
Fans made of feathers were known to have been used in China for over 2000 years, and such fans were possibly the earliest form of the accessory, used by men and women alike. The handles on most feather fans are normally made of wood or bamboo, but occasionally, carved ivory and jades were used by those in wealthier situations. 

This brightly coloured feathered fan, made in modern times, was possibly made under the influence of Western fashions in the early twentieth century, when accessories made of real feathers were in vogue. At the same time, the design of this fashionable accessory bears references to Chinese antiquity, in the form of a hardstone or glass handle carved with geometric patterns reminiscent of ancient bronzes. 

The fan might have been made or imported for the consumption of fashionable Chinese women exposed to current trends from Europe and America in the early twentieth century; alternatively, it is also possible that this was an accessory designed and made in China in response to the demands and tastes of women from expatriate communities who kept in touch with fashionable developments in the metropolis.
fields.bibliography: Related citation: "Angelia Calvocoressi 1840-1929: A Cosmopolitan Life" by Claire Brisby, Journal of the Hellenic Diaspora 30.2 (2004) pp. 97-130
fields.history_note:
Donated by Lady Logan from the collection of her parents, Robert and Alexandra Everts. Robert Everts (b. Brussels 12 Sept. 1875; d. Brussels 30 April 1942) was born in Brussels the son of the Dutch Consul who adopted Belgian nationality c.1898 and entered the Belgian Diplomatic Service, serving in Paris (1900-09), Mexico (1901-02) and Bucharest (1902-06). He married Alexandra (b. Corfu 4 Feb. 1880; d. Brussels 1961) whose mother was Angelia née Calvocoressi and who chose the family name Comnÿne, in Brussels in 1913. Alexandra accompanied her husband in his foreign postings to Peking between 1910-16 and again in 1920-24, Berlin 1924-31 and Madrid 1932-29 after which the couple resided in Brussels. Together they formed collections of Mexican armour, Mexican textiles, Puebla ceramics, Spanish colonial glass; Chinese textiles, Chinese and Japanese lacquer, Chinese furniture, ceramics and metalwork; and they preserved inherited period lace.

Parts of these collections have been acquired by museums internationally:
The British Museum: Mexican textiles and beadwork (1994 AM3.1, AM7.1-20; 1996 AM10 1-18; 1997 AM4.1)
Mexico City, Franz Mayer Museum: Mexican rebosos and textiles (1994 AD-004, AD-020;DRA-0009, DRA-0025; AD-021, AD-030; DCH-0001, DCH-0010; AD-031, AD-038; DFB-007, DFB-0014); Ecclesiastical embroidered panels, XVI century (2002 09157-01966; DCN-0013, FCF-0011-15; FPA-0013-16)

Alexandra Comnÿne-Everts was herself a proficient artist and designer. Albums of her drawings of ornament on Chinese monuments (c. 1919-25) have been acquired by the British Library (1998 N Or.15493/1-6) and the bridal tiara she commissioned from Cartier in Paris is on loan to the Victoria & Albert Museum.

The acquisitions from this collection in the Victoria & Albert Museum are:
Asian, set of 8 kessus (silk tapestry), late Ming period (T.269-G-1971); feather fan, carved jewelled handle, Chinese, c. 1910 (FE-2008)

Fashion, 20th century dress (T.12-203 – T.17-2003); Textiles, Belgian and Flemish lace (T.5-2003; T.6-T.10-2003; T.62-2008; T.63-2008; T.64-2008; T.65-2008)

Ref: Claire Brisby, ‘Angelia Calvocoressi 1840-1929: A Cosmopolitan Life’, Journal of the Hellenic Diaspora, 30.2 (2004), 97-130.

Related names Angelia Calvocoressi

NB The phrasing of this object history note is as provided by Claire Brisby, Lady Logan's daughter. It is given so that all objects donated by Lady Logan (including those in FTF and Metalwork) will have the same consistent record, as requested by donor. Please do not amend it.
fields.historical_context_note: Alexandra Comnène-Everts was herself a proficient artist and fashion designer and with her husband a discerning collector and patron in China.  Her drawings of ornament on Chinese monuments is in the British Library [N OR.15493/1-6].  The tiara Alexandra commissioned form Cartier in Paris for her wedding in 1913 is displayed in the Jewellery Gallery, Victoria and Albert Museum, on loan from Lady Logan.
